Hi Fredrik, very nice tsuba and not it is not a Chinese rip-off I can 
assu=
re you. Akasaka would fit, as would Tosa Myochin. I notice there is 
no car=
ving in the hira ( surface ) usually the tea whisks ( 3 and 9 
o'clock ) ha=
ve the brush ( whisk ) lines carved in them and the Ginger 
leaves ( 12 and=
 6 o'clock ) have usually 3 dots ( see this image 
http://www.nihontomessag=
eboard.com/tsuba_collection/akasaka_tadatoki_tea.jpg 
)
and 3 lines on them=
 as well. The surface does not look like Akasaka 
plate to me, I may be wro=
ng, it's quite rough and pitted up close. It 
could point to a late student=
s work I guess, or a late copy, none the 
less, I think it is a late tsuba,=
 as in the end of the Edo period sometime.

Just some ramblings LOL, they m=
ay be all wrong.

Rich
